thinking.disposable_income: Hermosa has a median household income of $66,073, with about 38% of households earning less than $50,000 annually. This suggests moderate disposable income levels, making residents sensitive to both transit fares and sales tax increases.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With a per capita income of $27,053 and average household size of 3.1, discretionary spending is likely limited. Many households need to carefully balance transportation costs with other essential expenses.
thinking.accessibility: 87.5% of households have at least one vehicle, with 60.9% driving alone to work. 17.7% use transit, indicating significant reliance on both modes. Good transportation access is crucial for this working-class community.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized lower sales tax (0.5%) to protect discretionary spending power. 2. Favored moderate transit fares ($1.25) to balance transit agency funding with affordability. 3. Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening the majority who drive. 4. Considered travel time improvements for both transit and driving given mixed mode usage. 5. Aimed to maintain accessibility while generating sufficient revenue for transit improvements.
